bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to L. O. Howard, May 14, 1900

div1.p: Reed is unable to help Howard with his mosquito investigation. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to L. O. Howard, May 14, 1900
div1.opener:
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES OF THE UNITED STATES * 1934 *
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Washington, D. C.
RECORDS OF THE DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE, Bureau of
Entomology and Plant Quarantine.
Three Centimeters
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
May 14, 1900
Dear Mr Howard:
div1.p:
I thank
you very much for the
kind offer contained in
your favor of the 12th Inst.
I have just, this morning,
received a short note
from Dr. Flexner asking
me to come to Philadelphia
in order to study the dysen-
tery bacillus with him
for a few weeks. I shall
soon see General Sternberg
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES OF THE UNITED STATES * 1934 *

THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Washington, D. C.

RECORDS OF THE DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE, Bureau of
Entomology and Plant Quarantine.

& find out what he thinks
of Flexner's proposition.
If I take up this work,
I suppose that a trip to
Cuba would probably
follow - and I would be
unable to take up the
mosquito work. I shall
know something more
definite within a few days
& will let you know --
The information concerning
the distribution of Meharhinus
& Psorophora is much appre-
ciated.
div1.closer:
Very truly, yours, Walter Reed. Mr L.O. Howard,
Entomologist
